title: Schema component name composed of English words
post: The English language has many spelling variations for the same word. For example, American English program has a corresponding British spelling programme. This variation has the potential to cause interoperability problems when XML components are exchanged because of the different names used by the same elements. title: Singular form is preferred in name
text: A noun used as a term in the name of an XML Schema component MUST be in singular form unless the concept itself is plural.

title: Component name follows pattern
pre: Elements in NIEM-conformant schemas are given names that follow a specific pattern. This pattern comes from [ISO 11179-5].
post: Consistent naming rules are helpful for users who wish to understand components with which they are unfamiliar, as well as for users to find components with known semantics. This rule establishes the basic structure for an element or attribute name, in line with the rules for names under [ISO 11179-5]. Note that many elements with complex type should not have a representation term.

title: Object-class term identifies concrete category
post: The object-class term indicates the object category that this data component describes or represents. This term provides valuable context and narrows the scope of the component to an actual class of things or concepts.
text: The object-class term of a NIEM component MUST consist of a term identifying a category of concrete concepts or entities.

title: Property term describes characteristic or subpart
post: The property term describes the central meaning of the data component.
text: A property term MUST describe or represent a characteristic or subpart of an entity or concept.

title: Name may have multiple qualifier terms
text: Multiple qualifier terms MAY be used within a component name as necessary to ensure clarity and uniqueness within its namespace and usage context.

title: Name has minimum necessary number of qualifier terms
text: The number of qualifier terms SHOULD be limited to the absolute minimum required to make the component name unique and understandable.

title: Order of qualifies is not significant
post: Very large vocabularies may have many similar and closely related properties and concepts. The use of object, property, and representation terms alone is often not sufficient to construct meaningful names that can uniquely distinguish such components. Qualifier terms provide additional context to resolve these subtleties. However, swapping the order of qualifiers rarely (if ever) changes meaning; qualifier ordering is no substitute for meaningful terms.

title: Redundant term in name is omitted
post: This rule, carried over from 11179, is designed to prevent repeating terms unnecessarily within component names. For example, this rule allows designers to avoid naming an element PersonFirstNameName.
